newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel money supply down 1.2 percent in October.
newsitem.headline: Israel money supply down 1.2 percent in October.

text.p: Israel's M1 money supply fell a preliminary 1.2 percent in October to 16.63 billion shekels following a 1.5 percent rise in September, the Bank of Israel said on Sunday.
Since the beginning of the year M1 has expanded 9.55 percent.
Total credit in October rose 2.3 percent to 246.6 billion shekels, led by a 3.5 percent increase in unlinked shekel credits to 81.2 billion shekels, it said.
The increase in credit followed slower rises of 0.8 and 1.0 percent in August and September, respectively.

Money supply figures are one of several the central bank uses to determine short-term interest rates, which are due to be announced on October 25. The current base rate is 15.2 percent and has been falling since August.

On Friday, the Central Bureau of Statistics reported that the October consumer price index rose 0.8 percent. The figure marked a sharp rise from the 0.4 percent increases in August and September, but economists said October inflation was usually higher due to seasonal factors.
